abstract.p: The definition of consonance as the ability to resolve a sound into the pitch categories is introduced.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Consonance in music has been a scientific issue ever since the pythagorean idea of scales with ratios of small whole numbers has been suggested. Rameau's famous "Traité de l'Harmonie" [8,1721] is the first to emphasize the importance of the harmonic series. However, its failure to explain consonant chords such as the minor triad led Helmholtz [1,1863] to develop a physical explanation of consonance in terms of beats. Two tones within a certain critical bandwidth show the phenomenon of "roughness", which can be attributed to dissonance.

Pierce [2] and Terhardt [10] have pointed out that an explanation of consonance with roughness and beats disregards the musical meaning of the interval between the notes of the chord in question. Other criteria, such as context, familiarity [10], prenatal conditioning and cultural conditioning [4] have been suggested to account for the subjective decision of "what goes well". A seventh of two sinusoidal tones displays no roughness.The dissonant effect might then be attributed to our familiarity to its dissonant role in Western music.

Krummhansl and Kessler [3,1982] have determined "key profiles" which encompass these criteria by an experimental method in which musicians were asked to judge how well each probe tone went with the tone or chord before. They used a multidimensional technique to produce maps of rela-tionships between chords, as well as predictions of corresponding keys to passages. It is shown that for a given major triad, the dominant, subdominant and parallel minor chord is detected as being related.This paper suggest a way to produce the key profiles theoretically:
The characteristic curve for roughness is obtained by the measure of how well the given chord resolves into the pitch categories.

This is not to be confused with the spectral resolving power of the ear! Pitch categories are about a semitone wide. and present the elements of the 12-tone scale to which people on the Western hemisphere are familiar. The categorical perception enables the listener to assign any audible harmonic to a complex tone. This freedom or lack of resolution power accounts for the chromatic scale being able to serve as a substitute for the diatonic scale.

div.head: Alternative definition of Consonance
div.p: Sounds are perceived by the ear by some kind of spectral analysis ( [2], [9]). Sano and Jenkins presented a connectionist model due to which the local information of the analysis on the basilar membrane ("transducer layer") is passed to a scale of pitch categories ("note layer") in the brain. "The motivation for the model derives from the fact that the inner hair cells in the cochlea, the primary transducers in the auditory system, respond to a range of frequencies".

In optics, one is confronted with the question of when two close spectral lines are to be called separate. The unability to make this decision shall be used here to define dissonance. Two closely neighboured pure tones display an overlap of the corresponding response distributions on the transducer layer. As an alternative approach to the roughness-theory, dissonance shall be viewed as the uncertainty in deciding which pitch category the particular harmonics belong to. The situation in figure 2 corresponds to two partials from different fundamental tones in a chord. They generally have different amplitudes. Usually these distributions are modelled by Roex-filters. In the present context Gaussian approximations are sufficiently exact. div.p: Consonance spectra have been taken of a synthesizer-version of a grandpiano (Yamaha DX 11). The first four bars of Bach's well known "Preludium" are subject to the analysis. The beginning of the piece is characterized by Figure 6: The 48 first chords of Bach's "Preludium" in C-Maj from "Das Wohltemperierte Klavier I" (c.:consonance, D.distance) two base-notes and a pair of three subsequently played "right-hand" notes. The higher notes are not sustained and can therefore be considered to fit into the harmonic context laid out by the introducing lower notes, which are sustained. The progression of these triads can be traced with the diagram of figure 7.

C stands for consonance, and c 1 ,c 2 are the number of semitones from the base tone. The first three chords have the coordinates (c 1 ,c 2 )=(4,7),(4,12),(4,16) at which the consonance clearly shows extremal values. The second progression of three chords belongs to (c 1 ,c 2 )=(2,9), (2,14), (2,7), and the third to (c 1 ,c 2 )=(3,7), (3,14), (3,17). All appearing consonancies show a value of C>0.4. As a result one can say that Bach seems to have picked chords with especially little roughness in the introduction of his "Preludium".

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: Visualization of consonance and correlation between chords serves as a useful tool to overlook harmonic relationships. Typically related chords are distinguishable in relevant diagrams ( Figure 8).
